channel.title: Swapping computer cases
channel.description:
I've been thinking about upgrading my computer case for a while, mainly because the airflow and space inside of my current in my current case is terrible.
My current case: http://h20000.www2.hp.com/bizsupport/TechSupport/Document.jsp?objectID=c02871948&prodSeriesId=5080737
Future (hopefully) case: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16811119245
I'm sure it's quite obvious the second case would definitely be an upgrade, but I was wondering if there would be any problems swapping out all of the parts in my current case, since the only thing in it that isn't stock is the PSU and GPU. By this, I mean, would it be possible/easy to take the parts out of my current case and move them into the other case. If so, what will I need (if any) in order to swap everything over?

item.title: Swapping computer cases
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Niall:

You don’t need an anti-static wrist band, just touch the unpainted side of a computer case. The case you linked may not have them but it’s guaranteed that your current one will.

I actually did get a wrist band just in-case. Everything went pretty good, except the fact it took a few hours; for it being my first time, I think everything was pretty smooth and to the point.

Check out my GPU temperature thread and give me your thoughts on my idle computer temperatures:

moparisthebest.com

moparisthebest.com

programming, irc, cars

Read full topic

item.title: Swapping computer cases
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

You don’t need an anti-static wrist band, just touch the unpainted side of a computer case. The case you linked may not have them but it’s guaranteed that your current one will.

item.title: Swapping computer cases
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

No problem, hope everything goes as planned.

Read full topic

item.title: Swapping computer cases
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“Travas, post:6, topic:518832”][quote author=Tutorial link=topic=637100.msg4295986#msg4295986 date=1368231319]

Extremely easy. Just watch out for ESD.

I’m assuming you are talking about electrostatic discharge?

And use an anti static wristband, I shorted my motherboard once because I didn’t, it does actually happen.

Do you think local areas might have them, such as Walmart or Radioshack? Also, is there any other safe way to work with computers and prevent this from happening? I was going to get a new motherboard anyways, but I’d really like to keep it just in case. :rolleyes:
[/quote]Indeed I’m talking about electrostatic discharge. As SilentCJ said, use a strap. You can get an entire toolkit from Walmart (and Radioshack I’m guessing) which contains screwdrivers for just about any type of bolt you will encounter, tweezers for when you drop a bolt or screw, and of course a strap for your wrist (which connects to the metal part of your case). I believe you can also just pick up a strap for a couple bucks from one of these stores, not sure though.

You can also buy antistatic bags for placing your unused parts in. They are also helpful when switching out components because you can set the part down on top of the bag itself so it doesn’t get ruined.[/quote]
I really appreciate the help, thanks!

Read full topic

item.title: Swapping computer cases
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

[quote=“Tutorial, post:5, topic:518832”][quote author=Travas link=topic=637100.msg4295578#msg4295578 date=1368148681]
Extremely easy. Just watch out for ESD.
[/quote]
I’m assuming you are talking about electrostatic discharge?

And use an anti static wristband, I shorted my motherboard once because I didn’t, it does actually happen.

Do you think local areas might have them, such as Walmart or Radioshack? Also, is there any other safe way to work with computers and prevent this from happening? I was going to get a new motherboard anyways, but I’d really like to keep it just in case. :rolleyes:[/quote]Indeed I’m talking about electrostatic discharge. As SilentCJ said, use a strap. You can get an entire toolkit from Walmart (and Radioshack I’m guessing) which contains screwdrivers for just about any type of bolt you will encounter, tweezers for when you drop a bolt or screw, and of course a strap for your wrist (which connects to the metal part of your case). I believe you can also just pick up a strap for a couple bucks from one of these stores, not sure though.

You can also buy antistatic bags for placing your unused parts in. They are also helpful when switching out components because you can set the part down on top of the bag itself so it doesn’t get ruined.

Read full topic

item.title: Swapping computer cases
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Travas:

Extremely easy. Just watch out for ESD.

I’m assuming you are talking about electrostatic discharge?

SilentCJ:

And use an anti static wristband, I shorted my motherboard once because I didn’t, it does actually happen.

Do you think local areas might have them, such as Walmart or Radioshack? Also, is there any other safe way to work with computers and prevent this from happening? I was going to get a new motherboard anyways, but I’d really like to keep it just in case. :rolleyes:

Read full topic
